title: 100 Questions about Indian Constitution Preamble and Fundamental Aspects
description: Comprehensive MCQ questions covering Preamble content, Constitution adoption, basic structure doctrine, constitutional values, and amendments

questions.question: Which date marks the adoption of the Indian Constitution by the Constituent Assembly?
questions.explanation: The Constituent Assembly of India adopted the Constitution on 26 November 1949, but it came into effect on 26 January 1950.

questions.question: On which date did the Indian Constitution come into force?
questions.explanation: The Constitution of India came into force on 26 January 1950, which is celebrated as Republic Day.

questions.question: Who moved the Objectives Resolution in the Constituent Assembly?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru moved the Objectives Resolution on December 13, 1946, which laid the foundation for the Preamble.

questions.question: When was the Objectives Resolution accepted by the Constituent Assembly?
questions.explanation: The Objectives Resolution was accepted by the Constituent Assembly on January 22, 1947.

questions.question: What does 'Sovereign' mean in the Indian context?

options.A: India is free from foreign control
options.B: India has supreme power within its territory

questions.explanation: Sovereignty means India has supreme and ultimate power internally and is independent from external control, having the authority to legislate on any subject without external interference.

questions.question: Which term was added to the Preamble by the 42nd Amendment?
questions.explanation: The word 'Socialist' was added to the Preamble by the 42nd Amendment in 1976 during the Emergency period.

questions.question: Which amendment added the terms 'Secular' and 'Integrity' to the Preamble?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment (1976) added 'Socialist,' 'Secular,' and 'Integrity' to the Preamble during the Emergency.

questions.question: When did the 42nd Amendment come into force?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment came into force on 3 January 1977, though some provisions were enforced on 1 February and 1 April 1977.

questions.question: What does 'Democratic' mean in the Preamble?
questions.explanation: Democratic means government by the people through universal adult franchise, with representative government and 'one person one vote' principle.

questions.question: Who was the President when the Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949?
questions.explanation: Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the President when the Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949, and he also became the first President of India.

questions.question: When was November 26 officially declared as Constitution Day?
questions.explanation: The Government of India officially declared November 26 as Constitution Day on November 19, 2015, via a gazette notification.

questions.question: Which year was declared as B.R. Ambedkar's 125th birth anniversary year?
questions.explanation: The year 2015 was celebrated as B.R. Ambedkar's 125th birth anniversary year, which led to the declaration of Constitution Day.

questions.question: What is the full form of 'Samvidhan Divas'?
questions.explanation: Samvidhan Divas is observed as both Constitution Day and National Law Day in India on November 26.

questions.question: When was the first Constitution Day celebrated?
questions.explanation: The first Constitution Day was celebrated on 26 November 2015 after its official declaration by the government.

questions.question: On which date did PM Modi announce Constitution Day celebration in 2015?
questions.explanation: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced Constitution Day celebration on October 11, 2015, during the laying of the foundation stone for B.R. Ambedkar's Statue of Equality.

questions.question: Which fundamental case established the Basic Structure Doctrine?
questions.explanation: The Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973) case established the Basic Structure Doctrine by a 7-6 majority.

questions.question: What was the majority decision in Kesavananda Bharati case?
questions.explanation: The Kesavananda Bharati case was decided by a narrow 7-6 majority, establishing the Basic Structure Doctrine.

questions.question: Which case first theorized the concept of 'basic features' in 1964?
questions.explanation: Justice J.R. Mudholkar first theorized 'basic features' in the Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan case (1964) in dissent.

questions.question: Which case was overruled by Kesavananda Bharati?
questions.explanation: The Kesavananda Bharati case (1973) overruled the Golaknath case (1967) which had held Fundamental Rights as transcendental.

questions.question: What did the Golaknath case hold?

options.B: Fundamental Rights are transcendental and beyond Parliament's reach

questions.explanation: The Golaknath case (1967) held that Fundamental Rights are 'transcendental' and beyond Parliament's reach through constitutional amendments.

questions.question: Which case reaffirmed the Basic Structure Doctrine in 1980?
questions.explanation: The Minerva Mills v. Union of India (1980) case reaffirmed and strengthened the Basic Structure Doctrine.

questions.question: Which constitutional provisions were struck down in Minerva Mills case?
questions.explanation: The Minerva Mills case struck down sections 4 and 55 of the 42nd Amendment for violating the basic structure.

questions.question: What does the Basic Structure Doctrine prevent?

options.A: Parliament from destroying fundamental elements of Constitution

questions.explanation: The Basic Structure Doctrine prevents Parliament from destroying or emasculating the fundamental elements of the Constitution through amendments.

questions.question: Which amendment was challenged in the Kesavananda Bharati case?
questions.explanation: All the Judges held that the 24th, 25th and 29th Amendment Acts are valid, which were challenged in the Kesavananda Bharati case.

questions.question: Which case in 1975/76 reaffirmed the Basic Structure Doctrine?
questions.explanation: The Indira Gandhi v. Raj Narain (1975/76) case reaffirmed the Basic Structure Doctrine by striking down Article 329A.

questions.question: What did Article 329A of the 39th Amendment try to do?

options.A: Provide special protection to PM and Speaker
options.B: Remove judicial review for high offices

questions.explanation: Article 329A was designed to place PM and Speaker elections outside judicial review and provide special protection, but it was struck down for violating the basic structure.

questions.question: What is sovereignty according to the Preamble?
questions.explanation: Sovereignty means the supreme and ultimate power resides with the people of India, establishing internal and external sovereignty.

questions.question: What does internal sovereignty refer to?

options.B: Relationship between state and individuals within territory

questions.explanation: Internal sovereignty refers to the relationship between the state and individuals within its territory, divided into executive, legislature, judiciary, and administrative organs.

questions.question: What does external sovereignty mean?

options.C: Ability to conduct foreign policy independently

questions.explanation: External sovereignty means independence of a state's will from other states, the ability to conduct foreign policy, and acquire/cede foreign territory.

questions.question: Who is the source of sovereignty according to the Preamble?
questions.explanation: The Preamble begins with 'We, the people of India,' establishing that sovereignty resides with the citizens of India.

questions.question: What is the core of socialist ideology in Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: India follows democratic socialism, aiming to achieve socialist goals through democratic, evolutionary, and non-violent means.

questions.question: What are the aims of socialism according to the Constitution?
questions.explanation: Socialism aims to achieve equitable distribution of wealth, distributive justice, and prevent concentration of wealth and resources.

questions.question: Where were socialist principles reflected before 1976?
questions.explanation: Socialist content existed in the Directive Principles of State Policy before the term 'Socialist' was added to the Preamble in 1976.

questions.question: What is the Indian model of socialism?
questions.explanation: Indian socialism differs from state socialism and embraces a mixed economy approach, allowing both private enterprise and state intervention.

questions.question: What does socialism enable the government to do?
questions.explanation: Socialism enables government to regulate land and industry, implement welfare measures, provide reservations, and prevent concentration of wealth.

questions.question: What is the meaning of secularism in India?

options.B: Principled distance with equal respect for all religions

questions.explanation: Indian secularism means principled distance with equal respect for all religions (sarva dharma sambhava), not strict separation like in Western models.

questions.question: Which articles guarantee freedom of religion?
questions.explanation: Articles 25-28 of the Constitution guarantee freedom to profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health.

questions.question: What does the state do under secularism?
questions.explanation: Under secularism, the state cannot discriminate based on religion and must treat all religious communities equally with neutral stance.

questions.question: When was secularism added to the Preamble?
questions.explanation: The term 'Secular' was added to the Preamble by the 42nd Amendment on December 18, 1976.

questions.question: Which case established secularism as part of basic structure?
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court in S.R. Bommai v. Union of India (1994) held secularism as part of the basic structure doctrine.

questions.question: What does democracy mean in political philosophy?
questions.explanation: Democracy is described as a concept of political philosophy practiced by culturally advanced and politically mature nations through governance by representatives.

questions.question: What is the voting age in India?
questions.explanation: The voting age in India is 18 years, which was reduced from 21 years by the 61st Amendment in 1989.

questions.question: What does 'one person one vote' principle mean?

options.A: Equal voting rights for all citizens

questions.explanation: 'One person one vote' principle means equal voting rights for all citizens, universal adult franchise, and no discrimination in voting rights.

questions.question: What are the types of democracy mentioned in the Preamble?
questions.explanation: The Preamble emphasizes political, social, and economic democracy, providing comprehensive democracy beyond just political representation.

questions.question: What protects democracy from tyrannical rulers?
questions.explanation: Constitutional provisions and fundamental rights protect democracy from tyrannical rulers and ensure protection for citizens.

questions.question: What does 'Republic' mean in the Constitution?
questions.explanation: Republic means the head of state is elected, not hereditary, and public offices are open to every citizen without discrimination.

questions.question: Who is the head of state in India?
questions.explanation: The President of India is the head of state, who is elected (not hereditary) for a fixed term in India's republican system.

questions.question: How is the President elected?
questions.explanation: The President of India is indirectly elected by an Electoral College consisting of elected members of both Houses of Parliament and Legislative Assemblies.

questions.question: What did the Constitution abolish?
questions.explanation: The Constitution abolished titles of nobility and hereditary privileges, establishing equality of citizenship and preventing privileged classes.

questions.question: What does republican character reinforce?
questions.explanation: Republican character reinforces governance as a public trust, promoting civic virtue and public service, and rejects monarchical and aristocratic privileges.

questions.question: How many types of constitutional amendments are there in India?
questions.explanation: There are three types of constitutional amendments in India: Simple Majority, Special Majority, and Ratified Special Majority Amendments.

questions.question: Which amendment articles govern constitutional amendments?
questions.explanation: Article 368 of the Constitution governs the power and procedure for amending the Constitution, with second and third types being under this article.

questions.question: What requires simple majority for amendment?
questions.explanation: Simple Majority Amendment must be passed by simple majority in each house of Parliament for certain matters like some parliamentary procedures.

questions.question: What requires special majority?
questions.explanation: Special Majority Amendment requires two-thirds majority of members present and voting and majority of total membership in each house for most constitutional amendments.

questions.question: What is required for ratified special majority amendments?
questions.explanation: Ratified Special Majority Amendment requires special majority in Parliament plus ratification by at least one-half of State Legislatures.

questions.question: Which amendment secured constitutional validity of zamindari abolition laws?
questions.explanation: The 1st Amendment Act (1951) secured constitutional validity of zamindari abolition laws and introduced Schedule 9 for protection from judicial review.

questions.question: Which amendment reorganized states on linguistic lines?
questions.explanation: The 7th Amendment (1956) reorganized states on linguistic lines, abolished Class A, B, C, D states, and introduced Union territories.

questions.question: What was introduced by the 52nd Amendment?
questions.explanation: The 52nd Amendment (1985) introduced the Anti-Defection Law through the 10th Schedule, providing for disqualification of members for defection.

questions.question: Which amendment reduced voting age from 21 to 18?
questions.explanation: The 61st Amendment (1989) reduced the voting age from 21 to 18 years, expanding democratic participation.

questions.question: When was GST introduced through constitutional amendment?
questions.explanation: The Constitution (101st Amendment) Act, 2017, introduced the Goods and Services Tax (GST), revolutionizing the indirect tax system.

questions.question: Which amendment gave constitutional status to GST Council?
questions.explanation: The Constitution (102nd Amendment) Act, 2018, gave constitutional status to the Goods and Services Tax Council.

questions.question: What was the main aim of the 1st Amendment?

options.B: Secure zamindari abolition and protect backward classes

questions.explanation: The 1st Amendment secured constitutional validity of zamindari abolition laws and provided special provisions for advancement of socially and educationally backward classes.

questions.question: Which amendment introduced Schedule 9?
questions.explanation: The 1st Amendment inserted Schedule 9 to protect laws contrary to fundamental rights (property, speech, equality) from judicial review.

questions.question: How many amendments have been made to the Indian Constitution as of July 2025?
questions.explanation: As of July 2025, there have been 106 amendments to the Constitution of India, making it one of the most amended constitutions globally.

questions.question: Why is Indian Constitution frequently amended?

options.B: Constitution spells out governmental powers in detail

questions.explanation: The Indian Constitution spells out governmental powers with such detail that many matters addressed by statute in other democracies must be addressed via constitutional amendment.

questions.question: How often is the Constitution amended approximately?
questions.explanation: The Constitution is amended roughly twice a year on average, reflecting the dynamic nature of India's constitutional framework.

questions.question: Which amendment dealt with property rights and compensation?
questions.explanation: The 25th Amendment (1971) restricted property rights and compensation in case the state takes over private property, and inserted Article 31C.

questions.question: What happened to Article 31C in Kesavananda Bharati case?

options.C: Partially quashed for taking away judicial review

questions.explanation: The Supreme Court quashed part of Article 31C (specifically clause 4) to the extent it took away the power of judicial review in Kesavananda Bharati case.

questions.question: Which amendment abolished privy purse?
questions.explanation: The 26th Amendment (1971) abolished the privy purse paid to former rulers of princely states that were incorporated into the Indian Republic.

questions.question: When were Fundamental Duties added?
questions.explanation: Fundamental Duties were prescribed by the 42nd Amendment in 1976, forming Part IVA of the Constitution.

questions.question: Which constitutional body was created by the 69th Amendment?

options.A: NCT of Delhi with legislative assembly

questions.explanation: The 69th Amendment provided for a legislative assembly and council of ministers for the National Capital Territory of Delhi (NCT of Delhi).

questions.question: What was established by the 73rd Amendment?
questions.explanation: The 73rd Amendment provided statutory provisions for Panchayati Raj as the third level of administration in villages.

questions.question: What was established by the 74th Amendment?
questions.explanation: The 74th Amendment provided statutory provisions for local administrative bodies as the third level of administration in urban areas such as towns and cities.

questions.question: Which amendments are considered most crucial for students?
questions.explanation: The amendments 1st, 7th, 42nd, 52nd, 61st, and 101st are considered most crucial as they had fundamental impact on property rights, state reorganization, Preamble changes, anti-defection, voting age, and GST respectively.

questions.question: Which case dealt with para 7 of the 10th Schedule?
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court in Kihoto Hollohan v. Zachillhu (1992) struck down para 7 of the 10th Schedule for contravening Article 368 of the Constitution.

questions.question: What did the 44th Amendment do regarding right to property?
questions.explanation: The 44th Amendment (1979) omitted Article 19(1)(f) which provided the right to property, making property a legal right rather than fundamental right.

questions.question: What was the main purpose of the 84th Amendment?

options.A: Extend usage of 1971 census for seat distribution
options.B: Extend usage of 2001 census for seat distribution

questions.explanation: The 84th Amendment extended the usage of 1971 national census population figures for state-wise distribution of parliamentary seats.

questions.question: Which amendment extended 2001 census usage for seat distribution?
questions.explanation: The 87th Amendment extended the usage of 2001 national census population figures for state-wise distribution of parliamentary seats.

questions.question: What did the 86th Amendment provide?
questions.explanation: The 86th Amendment (2002) provided the Right to Education until the age of fourteen by inserting Article 21A and amending Articles 45 and 51A.

questions.question: Which amendment increased the retirement age of High Court judges?
questions.explanation: The 15th Amendment (1963) raised the retirement age of High Court judges from 60 to 62 years.

questions.question: What is the significance of Article 334 regarding reservations?

options.B: Extends reservation periods for SCs, STs and Anglo-Indians

questions.explanation: Article 334 deals with reservation periods for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Anglo-Indian members in Parliament and State Assemblies, which has been extended multiple times.

questions.question: Which amendment changed the election of Vice President?
questions.explanation: The 11th Amendment (1961) changed the election of the Vice President to be by an Electoral College consisting of members of both Houses of Parliament.

questions.question: What did the 43rd Amendment do?
questions.explanation: The 43rd Amendment (1978) repealed some of the more restrictive amendments enacted through the 42nd Amendment after the revocation of the Emergency.

questions.question: Which amendment created special provisions for Nagaland?
questions.explanation: The 13th Amendment (1962) provided special protection under Article 371A for the newly created State of Nagaland.

questions.question: What did the 70th Amendment do regarding Presidential election?

options.B: Included NCT Delhi and Pondicherry in Presidential Electoral College

questions.explanation: The 70th Amendment included the National Capital Territory of Delhi and Union Territory of Pondicherry in the Electoral College for presidential election.

questions.question: Which amendment integrated Sikkim into India?
questions.explanation: The 36th Amendment (1975) formalized the formation of Sikkim as a State within the Indian Union by inserting Article 371F.

questions.question: What did the 38th Amendment do?

options.A: Enhanced powers of President and Governors to pass ordinances

questions.explanation: The 38th Amendment (1975) enhanced the powers of the President and Governors to pass ordinances by amending articles 123, 213, 239B, 352, 356, 359, and 360.

questions.question: Which amendment made constitutional bodies accountable?
questions.explanation: The 44th Amendment (1979) provided human rights safeguards and mechanisms to prevent abuse of executive and legislative authority, making constitutional bodies more accountable.

questions.question: What did the 48th Amendment address?
questions.explanation: The 48th Amendment (1985) permitted President's rule up to two years in the state of Punjab by amending Article 356.

questions.question: Which amendment added new official languages?
questions.explanation: The 71st Amendment (1992) included Konkani, Manipuri, and Nepali as official languages in Schedule 8 of the Constitution.

questions.question: What was the main achievement of the 80th Amendment?
questions.explanation: The 80th Amendment (2000) implemented the Tenth Finance Commission recommendation to simplify tax structures by pooling and sharing all taxes between states and centre.

questions.question: Which amendment enhanced reservation in promotions?
questions.explanation: The 77th Amendment (1995) made a technical amendment to protect reservation to SCs and STs employees in promotions.

questions.question: What did the 85th Amendment protect?
questions.explanation: The 85th Amendment (2002) protected Consequential seniority in case of promotions of SCs and STs employees.

questions.question: Which amendment exempted Arunachal Pradesh from reservations?
questions.explanation: The 83rd Amendment (2000) exempted Arunachal Pradesh from reservation for Scheduled Castes in Panchayati Raj institutions.

questions.question: What is the difference between adoption and commencement of Constitution?

options.B: Adoption is when Constitution was passed, commencement is when it became effective
options.C: Commencement is when Constitution was passed, adoption is when it became effective

questions.explanation: Adoption (26 November 1949) is when the Constituent Assembly passed/accepted the Constitution, while commencement (26 January 1950) is when it came into effect as law.

questions.question: Why was January 26 chosen for commencement?
questions.explanation: January 26 was chosen to honor the Purna Swaraj resolution of 1930, which declared complete self-governance from British rule.

questions.question: Which celebration includes Preamble reading in schools?
questions.explanation: Constitution Day (26 November) includes reading the Preamble in all schools as part of the official celebrations declared by the government.

questions.question: What do the Preamble values guarantee?
questions.explanation: The Preamble guarantees social, economic, and political justice to all citizens, along with liberty, equality, and fraternity.

questions.question: What does fraternity ensure?

options.C: Unity and integrity of the nation

questions.explanation: Fraternity ensures a sense of belonging and oneness, assures dignity of the individual, and maintains unity and integrity of the nation.

questions.question: What was the significance of the objectives resolution for constitutional framers?

options.B: It reflected the spirit and ideals of constitutional makers

questions.explanation: The objectives resolution reflects the spirit of constitutional makers and the ideals they cherished, including sovereignty, secularism, democracy, justice, liberty, and equality.
